name: anas-platyrhynchos
definition: A wild duck found almost worldwide, the male of which has a green head and neck. Most domestic ducks descend from the mallard.
description:
Mallard belongs to the waterfowl family and is the main ancestor of most breeds of domesticated ducks.

The male birds (drakes) have a glossy green head and are grey on their wings and belly, while the females have mainly brown-speckled plumage.

Both sexes have an area of white-bordered black or iridescent blue feathers called a speculum on their wings; males especially tend to have blue speculum feathers.

The mallard is 50 to 65 centimeters long, of which the body makes up around two-thirds the length.

It is often slightly heavier than most other dabbling ducks, weighing 700 grams to 1.6 kilograms.

Mallard prefers wetlands, where productive waters produce large amounts of floating, emergent and submerged vegetation.

Wetlands also produce a great deal of aquatic invertebrates on which mallards feed.

They can be found in many types of habitats throughout the country including lakes, rivers, streams, small ponds, swamps, marshlands, and water reservoirs.

Mallards consume a wide variety of foods, including vegetation, insects, worms, gastropods and arthropods, although they are not restricted to these.

They also take advantage of human food sources, such as gleaning grain from crops.

Most mallard hens breed as yearlings, but they may not have much success; studies show that older hens have much lower duckling mortality.

Pair bonding starts as early as October and continues through March. Males leave the hen soon after mating.

The hen usually lays 9 to 13 eggs in a nest on the ground near a body of water. Ducklings hatch after 26 to 28 days.

Newly hatched mallard ducks are capable of swimming, walking, and communicating with their mother.

Once hatched the female leads her ducklings to the water and abandons the nest.

The young ducklings stay with their mother for about 8 weeks, then become independent.

After the breeding season mallards form groups called flocks and migrate from colder, northern areas to warmer, southern areas.

Some mallards, however, may choose to stay through the winter in areas where there is enough food and shelter.

Mallards are diurnal, which means that they are most active during the day.

Mallards are preyed upon by a wide variety of predators, including humans, raccoons, cats, domestic dog, skunks, weasels, hawks, crows, ravens, magpies, turtles, snakes, and fish.

They are watchful and escape to the water when startled, including the young ducklings.

featured.caption:
Sexes are easily distinguished by color:

  • males have green heads, white collars and brown chests,
  • females are almost entirely covered with brown feathers.

facts.name: Mallard ducks are omnivores
facts.value: Mallard ducks are omnivores (eat plants and other animals). Their diet depends on the type of habitat and available food. They eat different kind of soft-bodied invertebrates such as insect larvae, snails, shrimps and worms. Aquatic vegetation is also on the menu of mallard ducks.

facts.name: Ducklings leave the nest at 13 hours age
facts.value: Ducklings are ready to leave the nest 13 to 16 hours after hatching. They are able to swim from the moment of birth.

facts.name: Migrate to south during the winter
facts.value: Mallard ducks migrate from the north to the south during the winter, to avoid low temperatures and lack of food.

facts.name: Can survive from 5 to 10 year
facts.value: Mallard ducks can survive from 5 to 10 year in the wild, but they rarely live that long. Oldest known mallard duck died at the age of 27 years.

facts.name: Monogamous from autumn to spring
facts.value: Mallard ducks find their mating partner in the autumn and live together until the spring, when mating season takes place. Females have only one mating partner, while males often mate with more than one female.

facts.name: Can reach 65 centimeters
facts.value: Mallard ducks can reach 50 to 65 centimeters in length and up to 1.6 kilograms of weight.

facts.name: Mallard ducks rarely dive to find food
facts.value: Mallard ducks rarely dive to find food. They usually consume plants and animals from the surface (or close to the surface) of the water. Mallard ducks also feed on the ground.

facts.name: Males are more colorful
facts.value: Males and females are easily distinguished by the color of the plumage. Males have green heads, white collars and brown chests. The rest of the body is grayish. Almost entire body of females is covered with brown feathers except bluish-purple wings.

facts.name: Best known by the "quack" sound
facts.value: Mallard ducks are best known by the "quack" sound that they produce. Typical quacks are produced by females. Males vocalize more quietly and produce rasping sound.

facts.name: Male mallard ducks are called drakes
facts.value: Male mallard ducks are called drakes. Females are known as hens. Group of mallard ducks is known as flock.

facts.name: Male leaves the female after fertilization
facts.value: Male leaves the female after successful fertilization. Female takes care of the eggs and ducklings after hatching.

facts.name: Strong muscles used for flying
facts.value: Mallard ducks have strong muscles used for flying and a wingspan of 81 to 98 centimeters. They can fly at the speed of 88 kilometers per hour.

facts.name: All domestic species are from mallard
facts.value: All domestic species of ducks originate from mallard ducks.

facts.name: Molt after the breeding season
facts.value: Mallard ducks molt after the breeding season. They are vulnerable during this period because they are unable to fly.

facts.name: Females lay from 8 to 13 eggs
facts.value: Females build nests in the ground and lay from 8 to 13 greenish-grayish eggs. Incubation period lasts 23 to 30 days.

related.definition: A large white swan of Europe and Asia, having a loud whooping call.
A goose of North America and Siberia that has two color forms, one with white plumage and black wingtips and the other with bluish-gray plumage and a white head.
The common goldeneye  is a medium-sized sea duck of the genus Bucephala, the goldeneyes.
